abstract: Appaloosa Investment will not be allowed to join in a lawsuit intended to foreclose on Manhattan’s Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartments, Bloomberg News reported.
snippet: Appaloosa Investment will not be allowed to join in a lawsuit intended to foreclose on Manhattan’s Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartments, Bloomberg News reported.
lead_paragraph: Appaloosa Investment will not be allowed to join in a lawsuit intended to foreclose on Manhattan’s Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartments, Bloomberg News reported.

abstract: Goldman Sachs and other big banks could see their earning reduced by billions of dollar if Congress approves tighter regulation of the derivatives market.
snippet: Goldman Sachs and other big banks could see their earning reduced by billions of dollar if Congress approves tighter regulation of the derivatives market.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs could lose up to 41 percent of its earnings if Congress approves tighter regulation of the derivatives market, according to an analysis by Bernstein Research. That’s equivalent to wiping away $3.9 billion in Goldman’s earnings this year if the stricter regulations were in effect for the entire 12 months, according to a subsequent analysis of the numbers by DealBook using Bernstein’s 2010 earnings-per-share estimates.

headline.main: Study: Derivatives Rules Would Cost Banks Billions

abstract: Already facing investigations on two fronts into its practices in the mortgage market, Goldman Sachs came under pressure from investors as well after Standard & Poor’s changed its rating to sell.
snippet: Already facing investigations on two fronts into its practices in the mortgage market, Goldman Sachs came under pressure from investors as well after Standard & Poor’s changed its rating to sell.
lead_paragraph: 2:33 p.m. | Updated Already facing investigations on two fronts into its practices in the mortgage market, Goldman Sachs came under pressure from investors as well on Friday.

headline.main: Goldman Shares Dive on Inquiries and Downgrades

abstract: Bank of America’s chief executive said Friday that he supported a $50 billion “orderly liquidation” fund for large financial firms, but that he thought it should be built up over time
snippet: Bank of America’s chief executive said Friday that he supported a $50 billion “orderly liquidation” fund for large financial firms, but that he thought it should be built up over time
lead_paragraph: Brian T. Moynihan, the chief executive of Bank of America, said Friday that he supported a $50 billion “orderly liquidation” fund for large financial firms, but that he thought it should be built up over time, Reuters reports.

headline.main: BofA’s Chief Favors Bank Rescue Fund, but…
